item.title: Richmond Avenue Students Soared with Hands-On STEM Drone Program
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Students at Richmond Avenue School soared beyond textbooks this summer as they built and programmed drones through a dynamic STEM Summer Program. From hands-on assembly to flight simulations, the initiative inspired problem-solving, teamwork, and future-ready skills in Atlantic City's next generation of innovators.
item.content:encoded:
Atlantic City Students Take Flight with Hands-On Drone Program

In Atlantic City, summer learning means more than books and classrooms — it means rising to new heights. Through an innovative STEM Drone Program at Richmond Avenue School, local students spent the season not only building drones, but also building confidence, collaboration, and career dreams.

This program was part of the city's broader effort to provide youth with immersive, future-ready experiences. Each summer, Atlantic City’s public schools continue to push learning beyond the traditional model — and this drone program proved just how powerful that can be.

Learning by Doing

Instead of passively absorbing facts, students rolled up their sleeves and assembled commercial-grade drones from the ground up. Using Rub iQ kits, they learned to wire motors, install cameras, and troubleshoot complicated circuitry. It was engineering in action — tactile, technical, and teamwork-driven.

“These are the most complex drones we’ve ever used,” said instructor Nabi Chowdhury, who guided the students through every challenge. “They learned to problem-solve and adapt, even when tools didn’t work as expected.”

From flight simulators to hands-on assembly, every step of the program pushed students to think critically and work together. For some, the learning curve was steep — and that’s exactly what made it meaningful.

Real-World Skills, Real Impact

Whether improvising with pliers to solve a mechanical issue or working through communication breakdowns as a team, students learned that success isn’t just about following instructions. It’s about curiosity, perseverance, and trust in one another.

Principal Shontai Harris encouraged students to connect their learning to real-world possibilities. “Drones are used in roofing, insurance, public safety — all kinds of industries,” Harris said. “What they’re doing here is engineering, and it’s valuable for so many career paths.”

Students also explored flight simulators to build the coordination and decision-making skills needed for real drone piloting. The experience sparked new ideas, new interests, and new connections between classmates from different backgrounds.

A Community That Lifts Its Youth

When technical issues arose due to GPS signal limitations downtown, students quickly adapted — switching to older drones and planning a future launch from a nearby beach. For educators like Allison Clark, the takeaway was clear: “They were taken out of their comfort zones and rose to the challenge.”

The program showed that when students are trusted with real tools and real responsibility, they respond with creativity, grit, and pride.

Why Atlantic City?

This STEM Drone Program is just one example of how Atlantic City continues to invest in its youth — not only in summer but year-round. From hands-on STEM camps and creative arts programs to job training and scholarships, the city is building pathways to opportunity.

Programs like this remind us why Atlantic City is more than a destination — it’s a community. A place where young people can see themselves reflected in their schools, their neighborhoods, and their future.

It’s a city where students don’t just learn — they launch.

‍

item.title: Atlantic City's Dolphin Field Revitalized with $1.33M Green Acres Grant
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City completed major improvements to Dolphin Field thanks to a $1.33 million grant from the Green Acres Program. Upgrades include new turf, lighting, fencing, and ADA accessibility, marking another step in the Small Administration’s commitment to better recreational facilities.
item.content:encoded:
A Stronger Field, A Stronger Future

In Atlantic City, parks and playfields are more than green spaces, they are gathering places, practice grounds, and community anchors. And now, thanks to a $1.33 million Green Acres Program grant, Dolphin Field has been fully revitalized, ready to serve the next generation of athletes, families, and fans.

Led by Mayor Marty Small, Sr., the transformation of Dolphin Field reflects the City of Atlantic City’s ongoing investment in public recreation. From the new turf and upgraded lighting, to renovated locker rooms, improved ADA accessibility, and modern fencing and landscaping, this project was designed to enhance both performance and safety — and to give residents a facility they can be proud of.

Where Community Comes to Play

More than just a sports field, Dolphin Field has long been a home for local football players, especially the Atlantic City Dolphins organization. When Mayor Small first announced the project alongside players, coaches, and supporters, it marked a renewed commitment to the role of sports in building confidence, teamwork, and belonging.

With these upgrades now completed, the space is once again ready to support weekend games, afterschool practices, and community gatherings. It’s a place where kids can chase dreams and families can cheer them on.

Local Support, Lasting Impact

The project would not have been possible without generous community partnerships. Local developer and Hard Rock Atlantic City owner Joe Jingoli previously contributed a new scoreboard and funding for earlier improvements, which remain an important part of the field today. The city has also applied for an additional $250,000 grant from the NFL to further enhance the facility.

This collaborative spirit between city leaders, local donors, and residents is what makes Atlantic City more than just a destination. It’s a place where people invest in each other.

A City Built on Momentum

Dolphin Field is just one piece of a much larger movement under the Small Administration. Across Atlantic City, playgrounds are being modernized, parks are being beautified, and public spaces are being made more inclusive. These projects are not just about infrastructure, but about identity. It's about building a city where people want to live, work, and grow.

For families, it means safer, more welcoming spaces. For youth, it means more opportunity to stay active, connected, and inspired.

Why Live in Atlantic City?

Because Atlantic City believes in its people. Whether it’s summer youth jobs, scholarships, cultural programming, or upgraded sports fields, this city continues to invest in the things that make communities thrive.

This summer, as residents enjoy the beach and boardwalk, they’ll also see the results of thoughtful, community-focused leadership at play — on fields like the Dolphin Field, and in neighborhoods all across the city.

item.title: Atlantic City Charges Ahead with New Public Electric Vehicles Stations at City Hall
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City powered up six new EV charging stations at City Hall, offering public access to fast and reliable electric vehicle charging. This move marked a bold step toward a cleaner, greener transportation future for residents and visitors alike.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City officially expanded its commitment to sustainability by installing six new EV charging stations at City Hall, located at 1301 Bacharach Boulevard. These chargers became publicly available and provided local drivers with a convenient, eco-friendly option to power their vehicles in the heart of the city.

The newly installed stations included four DC Fast Chargers and two Level 2 Chargers, all of which could be accessed via the ChargePoint app. Designed to accommodate a variety of electric vehicles, these stations were introduced to support Atlantic City's growing green infrastructure and help combat transportation-related emissions.

Transportation is one of the leading contributors to greenhouse gas emissions in urban areas. By offering modern charging solutions in a central location, the city demonstrated a proactive approach to environmental responsibility and urban innovation.

The chargers operated under standard charging rates, easily viewable within the app, and served as an important public resource for both residents and visitors who rely on electric transportation.

This milestone aligned with Atlantic City’s broader environmental goals, including reducing carbon emissions, encouraging cleaner energy adoption, and improving air quality. The charging stations represented not just technological progress, but also a cultural shift toward more sustainable urban living.

City leadership emphasized that these efforts were part of a long-term commitment to enhancing green transportation infrastructure and providing the tools needed for residents to make cleaner driving choices.

The installation of these EV chargers also complemented other sustainability initiatives already underway in Atlantic City, reflecting a unified strategy for environmental resilience.

By making these stations publicly available, the city took a meaningful step toward accessibility, equity, and environmental justice in clean energy.

With the addition of these EV chargers, the City of Atlantic City reaffirmed its dedication to building a cleaner, greener future, one charge at a time.

item.title: Atlantic City Beach Patrol Shines at Home in Lifeguard Classic
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Beach Patrol Race Team earned a strong third-place tie during the Atlantic City Lifeguard Classic, held right on their home turf at Albany Avenue Beach. With standout performances across multiple events, ACBP once again demonstrated excellence, teamwork, and pride in representing their city.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Beach Patrol (ACBP) Race Team delivered an impressive performance during the Atlantic City Lifeguard Classic, securing a third-place tie at their home beach on Albany Avenue. The competition, held in North Amityville, New York, showcased some of the region’s most skilled and dedicated lifeguards, and ACBP rose to the occasion with determination and strength.

In the Surf Dash, team members Emmett Kane, Andrew Gillman, Sabrine Ghazaz, and Ty Costabile led the way, capturing a first-place finish. Their speed and coordination set the tone for the rest of the competition and energized the entire squad.

The Doubles Row team of Vince Granese and Nick Guidara also climbed the podium with a third-place victory. Their precision and endurance in the surf demonstrated the high level of training and teamwork ACBP athletes bring to every event.

In the Doubles Rescue Race, Tom Muskett and John Swift tackled the surf with confidence and grit, representing the squad with honor in one of the most physically demanding contests of the day.

The team also put forth a strong effort in the Doubles Relay, with Michelle Burwell, Nick Guider, Julianna Granese, and Vince Granese working seamlessly together to complete the event with determination and skill.

In the Swim/Paddle Relay, Adam Schreiner, Adam Bailey, Harrison Gillman, and Mo Levin showcased versatility and stamina, further contributing to the team's overall standing.

Finally, John Swift represented ACBP in the Singles Row, rounding out the day’s races with a determined solo performance.

These results highlighted the exceptional training and camaraderie within the Atlantic City Beach Patrol, especially when competing on familiar sands. The team’s ability to tie for third among elite competitors from across the region is a proud moment for both the patrol and the community it protects.

With every competition, the ACBP Race Team continues to build on a legacy of excellence, safety, and sportsmanship. Their strong showing at the Lifeguard Classic is just one of many moments where Atlantic City’s finest lifeguards have proven their mettle in and out of the water.

item.title: Uptown Skate Park Launches a New Era for Atlantic City Community
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The grand opening of Uptown Skate Park marked more than just a new destination for skaters, it signaled Atlantic City’s continued investment in youth, community spaces, and inclusive summer opportunities where everyone can grow, move, and thrive.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer is more than just sand and surf, it’s about creating space for possibility. That spirit continues this season with the highly anticipated Grand Opening of Uptown Skate Park, a bold new addition to the city’s growing youth recreation landscape.

Located at Melrose and Massachusetts Avenues, the Uptown Skate Park is more than a concrete playground, it’s a symbol of Atlantic City’s commitment to building places where young people can move freely, build confidence, and connect with their community.

The effort has been championed by multiple local partners, including the Inlet Community Development Corporation and grassroots skate advocates like SkateAC, all working together to turn an underutilized lot into a destination for connection and movement.  Beneath the excitement lies something deeper: a shared vision for a more vibrant, inclusive, and youth-centered Atlantic City.

‍

‍

Why Atlantic City Builds for the Next Generation

‍
Skateboarding is more than a sport, it’s a culture rooted in creativity, resilience, and belonging. That’s why Atlantic City made it a priority to develop this space in the Uptown neighborhood, giving young residents a safe and exciting place to gather, practice, and grow.

Whether a beginner landing their first ollie or a seasoned skater competing in the trick contest, the park is designed to welcome everyone. And like all of the city's youth programs—from employment and leadership initiatives to arts mentorship and public safety academies, this project reflects a bigger goal: to meet young people where they are and support them in becoming who they want to be.

‍A Skatepark. A Signal. A Start.

‍
What makes the Uptown Skate Park special isn’t just the ramps or rails, it’s what they represent. By investing in community-driven projects like this, Atlantic City continues to show its deep belief in the power of public space to spark personal transformation.

And as youth carve their way across the park’s smooth surfaces this summer, they’re not just practicing tricks, they’re building confidence, forming friendships, and strengthening their ties to the community they call home.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
With the opening of Uptown Skate Park, Atlantic City affirms its place as a city where opportunity lives outside the classroom and off the clock. From Midtown to Inlet, and from Chelsea to the Beach Blocks, the city is working to ensure that every neighborhood is a place where youth can live fully, work purposefully, and grow with pride.

A City in Motion

‍
Skaters, students, artists, entrepreneurs, no matter the path, there’s space for everyone in Atlantic City’s future. Through ongoing investment in public amenities, creative programming, and inclusive infrastructure, the city is building not just for today, but for generations to come.

As wheels roll, music plays, and another summer unfolds, one thing is clear: Atlantic City isn’t standing still, it’s rolling forward, one skatepark at a time.

item.title: Texas Avenue School Renovation Marks Bold Step With Renovations
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Texas Avenue School underwent major renovations, including bold new paintwork, modern locker upgrades, and a turf playground installation. The improvements marked a new era for the historic building, aligning with the district’s larger mission to modernize school facilities across Atlantic City.
item.content:encoded:
The Texas Avenue School in Atlantic City underwent a significant transformation, marking the beginning of a new chapter for the historic institution. As part of the Atlantic City School District’s broader investment in modernizing educational facilities, the school received extensive updates that aimed to rejuvenate both its appearance and functionality.

Visible from the moment one approached the building, the most striking change was the new paint job, featuring bold red accents that reflected the school’s official colors. The fresh coat of paint revitalized both the exterior and hallways, giving the building a vibrant, contemporary look while honoring its long-standing identity.

Beyond the surface, the school addressed deeper infrastructure needs. The third floor saw the removal of outdated lockers, some of which had been in place for decades. These were replaced with sleek, modern units, offering students more secure and accessible storage solutions. This improvement aligned with the district’s goal to create safer and more student-friendly environments.

Outdoors, the school added a new turf playground, providing a durable, safe, and visually appealing surface for students to enjoy physical activity. This upgrade was especially impactful in encouraging active play while reducing maintenance needs.

Principal Lina Gil expressed pride in the project, emphasizing its broader effect on the school culture. “These projects have a significant impact on staff and students by enhancing the physical environment and sense of pride in the school community,” Gil said. Her words reflected a shared sentiment among faculty and families who welcomed the updates as a sign of renewed commitment to quality education.

The upgrades extended to future plans as well. A brand-new kitchen was in development to improve food service operations and support more efficient meal preparation. This improvement would not only enhance daily logistics but also contribute to better nutritional experiences for students.

The Texas Avenue School renovation was part of a larger district-wide initiative. Across Atlantic City, multiple schools received summer upgrades including HVAC system replacements, window installations, and classroom equipment enhancements, ensuring that students returned in the fall to facilities better suited for 21st-century learning.

As the first day of school approaches, Texas Avenue School stands as a powerful example of how thoughtful investment in infrastructure could support educational success. What had once been a century-old structure now felt like a beacon of renewal and readiness.

The City of Atlantic City celebrated a major milestone with the debut of the Health & Human Services Department’s first-ever Community Care Family Fun Day. The event brought together residents of all ages for a day filled with health, wellness, and fun, creating lasting memories and reinforcing the city’s commitment to public well-being.

Held in a family-friendly atmosphere, the event featured a variety of interactive activities, educational booths, health screenings, games, and live entertainment. Community members had the chance to learn about vital health resources while enjoying a day of connection and celebration.

The event marked a strategic effort by the Health & Human Services Department to engage directly with the community in a more personal and approachable setting. Through this initiative, the department aimed to promote wellness education, preventive care, and mental health awareness in a format that encouraged families to participate together.

City officials, healthcare partners, and volunteers worked collaboratively to make the event possible, setting up informative stations that addressed topics such as nutrition, fitness, stress management, and access to local health services. Many attendees took part in fitness demonstrations, wellness workshops, and hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and support healthier lifestyles.

In addition to the informative elements, Community Care Family Fun Day delivered on its promise of fun—with music, games, food, and prize giveaways that kept children and adults alike entertained throughout the day.

The event was also a celebration of community spirit, highlighting the importance of unity and collaboration in addressing public health challenges. item.title: Atlantic City Recognizes Pancho’s for Two Decades of Community Impact
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City honored Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria with the Ducktown AC Community Impact Award for its 20 years of service and cultural influence in the Ducktown neighborhood. Through the Keep It Local campaign, the city recognized Pancho’s lasting role in strengthening community ties and supporting local pride.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City, through its ongoing “Keep It Local” campaign, proudly celebrated the contributions of small businesses that serve as the heart and soul of the community. Spearheaded by the Economic Development division under the Planning & Development Department, the initiative highlighted businesses that have not only thrived economically but have also made a deep and lasting impact on the lives of residents. Among the honorees, one establishment stood out for its enduring presence and community influence—Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria.

The beloved Ducktown restaurant was honored with the Ducktown AC Community Impact Award, a recognition bestowed on businesses that embody community values, local pride, and long-term commitment to service. The award ceremony celebrated the legacy and contributions of Pancho’s, which has served the Ducktown neighborhood faithfully since 2005.

Founded by Fabiola Sanchez, Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria began as a humble yet passionate effort to bring authentic Mexican cuisine to the Atlantic City community. Over the years, it grew into more than just a restaurant—it became a place where families gathered, neighbors connected, and memories were made. Now under the leadership of Fabiola’s son, Joshua Cruz, the restaurant has continued to uphold its core values while evolving with the times.

From its flavorful tacos and savory burritos to its warm customer service and community engagement, Pancho’s has become a staple in the neighborhood, especially among locals who appreciate its consistency and cultural authenticity. The restaurant’s influence has gone beyond the menu—it has participated in local events, supported neighborhood causes, and helped foster a sense of belonging within Ducktown.

In accepting the Community Impact Award, Joshua Cruz expressed deep appreciation for the recognition, stating, "It’s been a long 20 years for all of us and to receive such an award is an honor." He went on to emphasize the restaurant’s commitment to staying true to its roots while continuing to serve the community with pride. "We’re very grateful to be acknowledged this way. Ducktown is our home, and the people here have supported us from day one," he shared.

The “Keep It Local” campaign is part of Atlantic City’s broader strategy to strengthen local commerce and promote sustainable neighborhood growth. By spotlighting businesses like Pancho’s, the city aims to inspire a culture of local appreciation and investment, encouraging residents and visitors alike to support homegrown establishments that reinvest in the community.

The recognition of Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria is not just about longevity—it is about impact. The restaurant’s ability to thrive for two decades in a dynamic, ever-changing cityscape reflects its adaptability, strong leadership, and unwavering dedication to quality. From first-time customers to loyal patrons, Pancho’s has created lasting impressions and continues to be a beacon of neighborhood pride.

As the city looks to the future, it is clear that small businesses will continue to play a critical role in shaping the identity and economic vitality of Atlantic City. With initiatives like the Keep It Local campaign, the city is doubling down on efforts to highlight the businesses that keep communities strong, resilient, and united.

For the residents of Ducktown and the broader Atlantic City area, Pancho’s Mexican Taqueria is more than just a place to eat—it’s a symbol of cultural richness, family legacy, and enduring community spirit.

item.title: Atlantic City Police Department Welcomes 15 New Officers After Graduation
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Fifteen new officers from the Atlantic City Police Department graduated from the Atlantic County Police Training Center and are now assigned to the Operations Division. The graduation ceremony for Class #30 took place at the Atlantic City Convention Center on July 24, 2025.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Police Department proudly announced the graduation of 15 new officers from the Atlantic County Police Training Center, marking a significant milestone in their journey to serve and protect the community. The graduation ceremony took place on July 24, 2025, at the Atlantic City Convention Center, celebrating the completion of Class #30.

Each officer successfully completed the rigorous training required to join the force, a testament to their dedication, discipline, and resilience. During the ceremony, Chief James Sarkos, along with Deputy Chiefs Andrew Leonard and Christian Garofalo, presented the graduates with their official certificates of completion, formally welcoming them into the department.

The officers will now begin their assignments within the Operations Division, where they will apply their skills on the streets of Atlantic City and contribute to community safety and law enforcement efforts.

Several members of Class 30 received special recognition for their outstanding performance:

  • John DeFeo earned the Sergeant Thomas Jerdan Firearms Proficiency Award.
  • Nicholas Leone was honored with the Officer Thomas J. McMeekin Award for Proficiency in Vehicle Operations, Physical Fitness, and received the Intensity Award.
  • Desiree Perez was recognized with the Physical Fitness Award - Most Improved.
  • Russell Lindsay served as Class President, a leadership role among peers.

Other graduating officers included Dominic Fornarotto, Russell Gilliam, William Hoff, Ethan LaMaina, Nicholas Leone, Seth Martinez, Rodriguez Moreno, Aayush Patel, Nimit Patel, Alexander Smith, Armando Valdivieso, and Eric Vargas.

The Atlantic City community looks forward to the fresh energy and commitment these new officers bring to the department. Their diverse backgrounds and strengths reflect the evolving needs of modern policing and the city’s dedication to safety and inclusion.

item.title: Bounce Out the Stigma Brings Inclusive Basketball and Empowerment to Atlantic City Youth
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Bounce Out the Stigma basketball camp brought together Atlantic City youth of all abilities for a day of skills, fun, and confidence-building. Led by Mighty Mike and supported by Atlantic City Recreation, the event proved that inclusion and play go hand in hand.
item.content:encoded:
Basketball, Belonging, and Big Wins: Inclusion Takes the Court in Atlantic City

In Atlantic City, summer means more than sunshine and boardwalk fun—it means opportunity for everyone, including youth with disabilities. Through programs like Bounce Out the Stigma, the city is redefining what inclusive recreation looks like—and why it matters.

Led by national speaker and coach Mike “Mighty Mike” Simmel, the Bounce Out the Stigma Basketball Clinic welcomed children of all abilities for a day of empowerment, movement, and teamwork. Designed for youth facing challenges such as autism, ADHD, and other developmental conditions, the camp offered more than basketball—it delivered confidence.

‍A City That Makes Inclusion a Priority

‍
Held in partnership with Atlantic City Recreation, the event was part of a broader effort to create programming where every child feels seen, safe, and celebrated. From learning basic drills to trying out Mighty Mike’s signature basketball tricks, participants explored new skills in a setting that was upbeat, accessible, and filled with encouragement.

As Mighty Mike shared with the group, the day was about more than games—it was about “drill skills and thrills” that strengthen both the body and spirit. Students were challenged to stretch beyond their comfort zones while building friendships, boosting motor skills, and unlocking their potential through play.

Why Atlantic City Believes in Its Youth

‍
According to Eric Brembert of Atlantic City Recreation, the city’s long-term vision includes making recreation accessible for all—whether through inclusive camps like this one or by expanding offerings citywide. In 2025, the city announced plans to add free swimming lessons, with a special focus on underserved neighborhoods like Island 48 blocks, where water safety education is critically needed.

The Bounce Out the Stigma clinic was more than just a one-day event—it was part of a growing movement in Atlantic City to create programming where inclusion isn’t an afterthought, but a foundation. Through collaboration, leadership, and community support, the city is opening doors for every resident to engage, grow, and thrive.

Real Confidence. Real Impact.

‍
What sets Atlantic City apart is the intention behind its programs. Leaders aren’t simply organizing events—they’re building platforms for transformation. Whether it’s a job training session, a leadership camp, or a basketball court filled with kids learning to believe in themselves, the message is the same: you belong here.

And when a child with sensory challenges feels safe enough to shoot a basket—or when a first-time participant runs to join their team with excitement—that’s the kind of impact that lasts.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
Programs like Bounce Out the Stigma represent why Atlantic City is more than just a vacation destination—it’s a community where families of all kinds can live fully, grow confidently, and build meaningful connections. Here, summer is a season of belonging, and every neighborhood is part of the movement to make opportunity accessible to all.

A City in Motion

‍
With inclusive programming, visionary partnerships, and a commitment to youth empowerment, Atlantic City is not just responding to its community’s needs—it’s anticipating them. As leaders continue to expand access across all ages and abilities, the city is proving that when everyone has a place to play, everyone wins.

This summer and every summer, Atlantic City continues to show the world what inclusion looks like in action—one child, one game, and one joyful moment at a time.

item.title: Atlantic City Fire Department’s Youth Explorer Program Sparks Interest in Lifesaving Careers
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Fire Department Youth Explorer Program gave local youth a unique introduction to emergency response and water safety, partnering with the Beach Patrol to deliver skills and confidence that could spark future careers. With tripled enrollment and repeat participants, the program proved its lasting impact.
item.content:encoded:
Where Courage Meets Curiosity: Atlantic City’s Youth Explorer Program Ignites a Passion for Public Safety

‍

In Atlantic City, summer is more than just a season—it’s a platform for purpose. Through programs like the Youth Explorer Program hosted by the Atlantic City Fire Department, local youth are gaining more than experience—they’re gaining direction.

Now in its third year, the Youth Explorer Program continued to thrive as it offered students a hands-on introduction to emergency services, lifesaving skills, and real-world leadership training. It’s become one of the city’s most sought-after summer experiences, reflecting a broader mission: to equip Atlantic City’s next generation with the tools they need to lead.

A Community That Invests in the Future

‍
Led by Deputy Chief Dwayne Brock, a 26-year veteran of the fire department, the program gave participants access to skills often reserved for professionals—CPR training, rescue simulations, water safety techniques, and more. In partnership with the Atlantic City Beach Patrol, students also received practical instruction in junior lifeguard duties, including rowing and surf awareness.

But beyond the drills and demonstrations, the Youth Explorer Program offered something deeper: confidence. For many young people, it was their first experience being part of a structured team environment that demanded discipline and rewarded curiosity. They left not only with certifications and safety pamphlets—but with purpose.

‍

Why Atlantic City Believes in Its Youth

‍
Every summer, more students are signing up—and coming back. With enrollment tripling since the program went digital, the Fire Department has welcomed a growing number of participants each year, many of whom have joined the program multiple times. This recurring interest speaks volumes: young people in Atlantic City are eager for challenge, mentorship, and meaningful opportunity.

As Deputy Chief Brock emphasized, early exposure to career pathways—and the professionals who guide them—can change a life’s trajectory. The program’s returning students are proof that when youth are inspired, encouraged, and believed in, they rise.

Building Confidence Through Service

‍
The Explorer Program isn’t just about firefighting. It’s about community. Through mock emergency scenarios and firehouse tours, students got an inside look at what it means to serve—and protect—a city. They asked questions. They practiced. And most importantly, they discovered their own capacity to lead in moments that matter.

For some, this experience will spark a lifelong passion for public safety. For others, it may be their first taste of teamwork, courage, and personal accountability. Either way, they leave better prepared for whatever future they

Why Atlantic City?

‍
Programs like the Youth Explorer Program are part of what makes Atlantic City such a powerful place to live, work, and grow. The city doesn’t just entertain—it empowers. From free youth initiatives and leadership camps to arts mentorship and workforce training, Atlantic City creates space for young people to discover who they are and where they’re headed.

A City That Moves with Purpose

‍
Every summer, while others may be vacationing, Atlantic City’s youth are in motion—learning, building, and becoming. With the support of mentors like Deputy Chief Brock and the Atlantic City Fire Department, the next generation is rising, equipped with more than skills—they’re armed with confidence, civic pride, and a drive to serve.

And that’s what makes Atlantic City not just a destination, but a community where young leaders are forged—every summer, one spark at a time.

item.title: From Camp to Career: Atlantic City Youth Trained for the Future in Junior Police Academy
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The AC’s Junior Police Academy challenged and empowered 11- and 12-year-olds through discipline, fitness, and leadership, creating lasting impact beyond summer. With alumni now serving as officers, the program proved it was more than a camp—it was a foundation for life.
item.content:encoded:
Discipline. Leadership. Purpose.

‍
Every summer, while some cities slow down, Atlantic City powers up with programs designed to shape its future. One of the most transformative examples is the Junior Police Academy—a two-week experience that gives local youth more than just a taste of law enforcement. It gives them the tools to lead.

Hosted by the Atlantic City Police Department, the Junior Police Academy is open to rising fifth and sixth graders, ages 11 and 12. It’s a structured yet inspiring summer journey that blends discipline, physical fitness, character-building, and teamwork, all wrapped in a supportive and motivating environment.

Where Futures Begin

‍
Each year, dozens of students enroll not knowing what to expect. Some are nervous about the physical challenges. Others have never spoken in front of a group. But by the end of the program, they’re standing taller—more confident, more focused, and more connected to the idea that greatness comes through hard work.

‍

From military drills and public speaking to locker inspections and leadership elections, every part of the academy is intentional. It’s not about creating future officers—it’s about preparing future leaders. Students are encouraged to push past fear, to speak up, and to support one another as teammates. They also learn the importance of physical wellness, mental toughness, and resilience—skills they’ll carry far beyond the classroom.

A City That Believes in Its Youth

‍
Like many youth-focused initiatives in Atlantic City, the Junior Police Academy is rooted in the belief that structure and support can change lives. Officers involved in the program mentor students not just for two weeks, but for life. That mentorship has already made a generational impact: three past academy graduates are now full-time police officers—two in Atlantic City, one in Ocean City.

After a summer of drills, training, and education (with a little fun along the way), this year’s class celebrated their graduation—marking the close of another season of growth and the beginning of something much bigger.

Why Atlantic City?

‍
The Junior Police Academy is one of several summer programs that reflect what makes Atlantic City a great community—not just for entertainment or vacation, but to live, to work, and to grow. These opportunities are part of a larger citywide commitment to creating spaces where young people are seen, supported, and inspired.

From the Mayor’s scholarship initiatives and Summer Youth Employment Program, to neighborhood events and creative mentorship programs, Atlantic City is investing in its next generation with purpose.

A City in Motion

‍
Every summer, the city takes bold steps forward. Through public safety programs, arts and culture initiatives, educational investments, and youth development opportunities, Atlantic City continues to prove what locals already know: this is a city that believes in its people—especially its young ones.

Whether it’s on the boardwalk, at a community center, or standing in line at morning formation—opportunity lives here.

item.title: Atlantic City’s Summer Youth Program Prepares the Next Generation for Success
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Atlantic City Summer Youth Work Program brought skills, inclusion, and confidence-building to life with hands-on activities, mentorship, and community partnerships like Bounce Out the Stigma. From sewing to self-empowerment, Atlantic City gave its youth every reason to believe in a brighter future.
item.content:encoded:
In Atlantic City, summer isn’t just a time for beaches and boardwalks, it’s also a season of opportunity. Through the Summer Youth Employment Program, the City of Atlantic City is giving local teens and young adults more than just a summer job. It’s offering them a launchpad into the future.

Spearheaded by the City of Atlantic City’s Youth Services Division, this initiative pairs local youth with hands-on job placements across the city, from government offices and community-based organizations. Participants are matched with opportunities that reflect their interests and career goals, building real-world skills in communication, leadership, and time management.

A City That Believes in Its Youth

Now in its latest year, the Summer Youth Employment Program has grown into a cornerstone of the city’s youth development strategy. It’s part of Mayor Small’s broader commitment to creating pathways to success for Atlantic City’s next generation, especially those who may not otherwise have access to these types of opportunities.

In recent years, the program has supported hundreds of local youth with paid job experience, professional development workshops, financial literacy training, and mentorship — all while instilling a sense of civic pride and community engagement.

Real Jobs. Real Impact.

What sets Atlantic City’s program apart is its emphasis on meaningful work. Participants are not observers — they are contributors. They help coordinate events, support local youth and seniors, assist in marketing campaigns, and even contribute to civic storytelling through platforms like GreatDayAtlanticCity.com.

These roles are more than resume-builders. They’re confidence-builders.

Why #LiveinAC?

The Summer Youth Employment Program is just one example of why Atlantic City is more than a summer destination, it’s a community where young people can see a future for themselves.

From the Mayor’s $3M scholarship initiative and the Small Business Academy, to free summer events, beach concerts, and family programming across all neighborhoods, Atlantic City is evolving into a place where opportunity lives year-round.

A City in Motion

Beyond the youth program, Atlantic City is investing in walkable neighborhoods, public art, affordable housing, and small business support. These efforts are reshaping the city’s reputation by showing the world what locals already know: Atlantic City is a place to live, work, and thrive.

This summer, as tourists soak in the sun, local teens will be busy making connections, gaining skills, and discovering their own power to shape the city they call home.

item.content:encoded:
The Great Day Summer Camp youth experienced an exciting adventure at the historic Steel Pier, where laughter echoed through the rides and sweet treats made the day even more special. This memorable outing, hosted by Atlantic City Youth Services in collaboration with Atlantic City Recreation, was filled with nonstop joy, bonding, and the kind of happiness only summer can bring.

From thrilling amusement rides to classic boardwalk snacks, the children created memories that embodied the spirit of the season. item.title: How a Summer Garden Brought Brighton Avenue School and Community Closer Than Ever
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The Brighton Botanical Garden bloomed into more than just a school project this summer. Through shared care, learning, and the joy of harvest, it became a symbol of growth, teamwork, and community pride.
item.content:encoded:
While many students at Brighton Avenue School welcomed their break, a different kind of learning continued to grow in the school’s front yard — within the vibrant space known as the Brighton Botanical Garden.

Rather than letting the flourishing garden go untended, the school’s Summer Program turned it into a daily hands-on learning hub. Staff and students arrived each morning to the scent of fresh herbs, the sight of leafy vegetables, and the chance to contribute to something meaningful.

The experience quickly became more than just gardening. It nurtured teamwork and ownership. “We all pitched in and helped,” said Principal Jason Grimes. “The parents from our school leadership team donated the dirt.” This generosity laid the foundation — quite literally — for a summer of discovery.

Students learned how to water, weed, and manage pests. For many, it was their first real introduction to sustainable gardening, teaching them patience, respect for nature, and the satisfaction of watching their work come to life. Even staff members unfamiliar with gardening found themselves learning side by side with the kids.

A major milestone came with the garden’s first harvest — thick, crisp cucumbers that matched the quality of any store-bought variety. “We taught the kids how to make a cucumber salad,” Grimes said, celebrating the garden’s transition from science lab to kitchen table.

The garden became a bridge between home and school. Parents who had helped early on with soil and supplies returned throughout the summer to weed, water, and check in on the garden’s progress. Their continued involvement turned the project into a true community collaboration.

Looking ahead, the Summer Program prepared the space for the upcoming school year. Staff and students began to plant cover crops, apply mulch, and ready the soil for fall’s next big goal: harvesting pumpkins before the winter chill sets in.

What began as a seasonal activity had evolved into a symbol of what’s possible when students, educators, and families work together. The Brighton Botanical Garden became a shared success — a living, growing testament to resilience, creativity, and community spirit.

“This is truly a community effort,” Principal Grimes reflected — a statement that echoed through every vine, root, and bite of cucumber.

item.title: Strengthening the Shoreline: Atlantic City Begins $8.5M Chelsea Bulkhead Project to Advance Storm Resiliency
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: The City of Atlantic City has begun construction on an $8.5 million Bulkhead Replacement Project in the Chelsea neighborhood, continuing its mission to improve storm resiliency. The project, funded through a grant from the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs, is a key component of a broader strategy to protect vulnerable communities from future flooding.
item.content:encoded:
As part of its long-term vision to combat the growing threats of climate change and coastal flooding, the City of Atlantic City officially began construction on an $8.5 million Bulkhead Replacement Project in the Chelsea neighborhood on July 23, 2025. The project is one of many ongoing efforts aimed at making the city more resilient against storms and tidal surges.

The construction, managed by Richard E. Pierson Company, included replacing public bulkheads along the back bay from Albany Avenue to Morris Avenue. In addition to the structural upgrades, improvements were made to stormwater outfalls, sidewalks were restored, and new trees were planted, adding both function and aesthetic value to the neighborhood.

The project is funded by a grant from the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs (DCA) and reflects the city’s strategic investment in community protection. Mayor Marty Small, Sr. emphasized that this initiative is aligned with his administration’s promise to prioritize resiliency, while also being mindful of taxpayer interests.

“The Small Administration has made a commitment to sure up our resiliency here in the Great City of Atlantic City with the best interest of our taxpayers in mind,” stated Mayor Small. “Through various projects like this, we are not only protecting our residents and businesses, but we are also investing in the future of our community.”

Beyond Chelsea, the city has launched or planned several other major infrastructure upgrades. A $16 million upgrade of the Atlantis Avenue Pump Station is expected to be completed by the end of the year. This station will help manage stormwater across Midtown and Inlet neighborhoods, reducing the risk of localized flooding.

In addition, the Ducktown Bulkhead Replacement Project and Fisherman’s Park Pump Station upgrades are scheduled to begin before the year ends. Both initiatives are partially funded by the U.S. Economic Development Agency, and represent a continuation of the city’s partnership with federal and state entities to secure funding for critical projects.

Jim Rutala, the city’s grant consultant from Rutala Associates, noted that the foundation for this comprehensive resiliency strategy was developed as early as 2012. He emphasized that the real momentum came after Mayor Small took office, resulting in a wave of successful grant applications and carefully executed infrastructure projects.

According to City Engineering Director Uzo Ahiarakwe, the Chelsea Bulkhead Replacement is just one piece of a broader puzzle. “Under this current administration there has been a strong emphasis on resiliency and addressing quality of life concerns. Chelsea bulkhead Replacement is one part of a comprehensive package in which we’re trying to address each and every component of resiliency.”

Already, previous phases of bulkhead improvements have been completed in Lower Chelsea, Chelsea Heights, and Gardner’s Basin. Additionally, most of the check valves regulating stormwater discharge have been upgraded. The city also celebrated the nearing completion of the $60 million Inlet Seawall and boardwalk project, providing a vital line of defense for the Inlet neighborhood and linking Ocean Casino Resort to Gardner’s Basin Park.

Looking forward, the city is preparing the next generation of resiliency projects. FEMA-funded studies are underway in Bungalow Park, Venice Park, Chelsea/Ducktown, and Chelsea Heights, which will inform future infrastructure and environmental improvements as funding becomes available. These studies demonstrate Atlantic City’s commitment to long-term preparedness in the face of environmental challenges.

The event drew in residents of all ages and backgrounds, uniting them through a shared appreciation for nature and community development. It served as a powerful reminder that beauty and growth can flourish in even the most unexpected corners of a city.

item.title: Investing in the Future: Atlantic City Honors 113 Local Scholars at Steel Pier

item.description: The City of Atlantic City proudly celebrated the 2025 Mayor Marty Small, Sr. Scholarship recipients with a heartfelt ceremony at Steel Pier, honoring academic achievement, resilience, and the city’s commitment to youth success. A total of 113 students were awarded scholarships of up to $10,000 each, bringing hope and opportunity to the next generation of leaders.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City turned its spotlight on the future by hosting a powerful and emotional celebration at the historic Steel Pier. The occasion honored 113 recipients of the Mayor Marty Small, Sr. Scholarship, recognizing the academic achievements, dreams, and determination of local students who represent the city’s next generation of leaders.

The event was a true community moment, filled with pride, hope, and gratitude. Students stood proudly alongside their families as they accepted their ceremonial checks, posed for photos with Mayor Marty Small, Sr., and shared in the excitement of a milestone that brings them one step closer to achieving their academic and career goals.

Each scholarship, valued at up to $10,000, was awarded to eligible Atlantic City residents. The recipients included a diverse mix of students—incoming college freshmen, current undergraduates, and those pursuing Masters, Doctorate, or Trade School education. This year’s group represented a wide range of aspirations: future nurses, engineers, educators, entrepreneurs, and more.

Funds were split into two disbursements—half for Fall 2025, and half for Spring 2026—to ensure continued support throughout the school year. While the checks handed out during the event were symbolic, the real funds were sent directly to the recipients’ academic institutions, reinforcing accountability and purpose.

‍

The choice of Steel Pier as the venue was symbolic. With its rich history and iconic status, the Pier represented resilience, renewal, and the city’s ability to evolve while staying grounded in community values. Against the backdrop of the Atlantic Ocean, the event reflected Atlantic City’s enduring spirit and its bright future.

In his address, Mayor Marty Small, Sr. spoke from the heart. He shared how deeply committed his administration is to uplifting youth, removing barriers to education, and building pathways to success. Since the scholarship program launched in 2023, it has awarded hundreds of Atlantic City residents with direct financial support—made possible through the city's allocation of American Rescue Plan funds under the "Addressing Educational Disparity" category.

This year’s awards expanded eligibility beyond just Atlantic City High School students, opening doors for all residents regardless of what high school they attend or attended. That inclusiveness contributed to a record number of applications in 2025, demonstrating a growing awareness and demand for educational opportunity in the city.

The presence of parents, educators, mentors, and city leaders made the event even more meaningful. They served as living proof of the power of a community that comes together to invest in its youth. Their cheers, applause, and tearful moments reminded everyone of what this celebration truly stood for—opportunity, equity, and hope.

#LiveinAC: A City That Believes in Its Students

Beyond the celebration itself, the event was a powerful call to action. It reminded residents, alumni, and stakeholders that supporting education is a shared responsibility. Whether through mentoring, sponsorship, or simply sharing resources, everyone has a role to play in shaping the future of Atlantic City’s young people.

By honoring these scholars, the city not only celebrated achievement but also sent a strong message: Atlantic City believes in its students. That belief is now being carried by 113 individuals who will go on to pursue their education with confidence and pride.

#InvestinAC: Scholarships That Change Lives

The 2025 Mayor Marty Small, Sr. Scholarship Celebration was more than just an event—it was a statement of purpose. It was a reminder that when a city invests in education, it plants the seeds for lasting change, not just in one life—but across generations.

Programs like this make Atlantic City more than a beach destination—they make it a place where families can thrive, where young people can see a future, and where investment in people drives progress.

item.title: A Creative and Adventurous Week 3 at Great Day Summer Camp
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic Contributors
item.description: Week 3 of Great Day Summer Camp was packed with creativity, learning, and unforgettable moments — from planting succulents to witnessing the Atlantic City Airshow. Campers explored nature, art, and adventure in a week that truly lived up to its name.
item.content:encoded:
Week 3 of Great Day Summer Camp, hosted by the City of Atlantic City Multicultural Services, offered a full lineup of exploration, creativity, and hands-on fun for campers of all ages. Each day introduced a new theme and set of activities designed to inspire, educate, and engage — and the results were nothing short of amazing.

Monday kicked off with Nature Day, where campers painted planter pots and planted their own succulents to take home. With dirt on their hands and smiles on their faces, they learned the importance of caring for living things and the joy of nurturing their own plants.

On Tuesday, the camp moved into a more artistic space with a visit to the Noyes Arts Garage. The spotlight was on Vincent van Gogh, as campers experimented with the impasto technique and created textured paintings inspired by the master himself. The creativity was flowing, and the results were colorful and deeply personal works of art.

Wednesday brought an extra dose of adventure. Our K–2 campers stepped into fantasy at Storybook Land, where fairy tales came alive through rides and attractions. Meanwhile, our 3rd–6th graders experienced the awe of the Atlantic City Airshow, watching jets soar across the sky in an unforgettable aerial performance.

The week wrapped up with a trip to the Cape May Zoo on Thursday. Surrounded by animals and lush greenery, campers enjoyed an up-close look at wildlife while learning about conservation and animal habitats. From lions to lemurs, every encounter was met with excitement and curiosity.

Every day of camp was more than just fun — it was a chance for campers to express themselves, connect with others, and explore the world around them. The thoughtful programming ensured that each child walked away with both memories and meaningful experiences.

The week’s theme may have been about nature, art, and adventure, but the heart of it was connection — to creativity, to community, and to each other.

It truly was a Great Day week. We’re so proud of what our campers accomplished and experienced, and we can’t wait to share what’s in store for Week 4.

Stay tuned — the adventure continues!

Jets streaked across the sky with precision and power, demonstrating the immense talent of the pilots and the coordination behind each flight maneuver. The roar of engines, the sharp turns, and the seamless formations were not just thrilling — they were a testament to the excellence of our armed forces and aviation teams.

Spectators lined the beach, boardwalk, and rooftops, capturing photos and videos of the dazzling aerial displays. For many, it was their first time seeing such stunts up close, and the energy in the city was electric.

City officials and visitors alike agreed that if the Practice Day was any indication, the main show would be truly unforgettable. The airshow is more than a series of flyovers — it's a celebration of skill, discipline, and community pride.

Local businesses, hotels, and restaurants also saw a positive boost in activity as visitors poured into town for the event. The airshow continues to be a major economic and cultural driver for the city.

For those planning to catch the main event, the full schedule was made available at:
https://www.visitatlanticcity.com/soarandshorefestival/

As the sun set on yesterday’s preview, excitement only grew. Atlantic City is proud to host an event that brings together families, veterans, aviation enthusiasts, and tourists for a shared experience in the skies.

item.title: Major Upgrades Transformed Atlantic City's Uptown School Complex This Summer
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Uptown School Complex underwent major upgrades this summer, including HVAC improvements, a new roof, and interior renovations. While work progressed, the school community embraced collaboration and creativity through shared summer programs with Pennsylvania Avenue School.
item.content:encoded:
The Uptown School Complex in Atlantic City underwent major capital improvements this summer as part of a district-wide initiative to enhance infrastructure and learning environments. These upgrades marked a transformative phase in the school’s development and demonstrated a deep commitment to student success, safety, and innovation.

Completed projects included the installation of a new roof, significant upgrades to the HVAC and boiler systems, and the replacement of interior doors. Each improvement was aimed at increasing energy efficiency, building sustainability, and maintaining a safe learning space for students and staff alike.

“These capital improvements at Uptown School Complex reflected our district’s ongoing commitment to providing safe spaces where students could learn and thrive,” said Superintendent of Schools Dr. La’Quetta S. Small.

While construction was underway, Uptown’s summer school program was temporarily relocated to Pennsylvania Avenue School. This transition created opportunities for stronger inter-school cooperation and led to a shared sense of purpose among educators and families. “I was incredibly proud of the collaboration between our school leaders, teachers, and families to ensure uninterrupted summer learning,” said Dr. Small.

The relocation allowed both schools to jointly launch new initiatives, including a Visual and Performing Arts program. The highlight was a joint production of 101 Dalmatians Kids, which featured a combined cast and creative team. “It helped build camaraderie rather than competition,” said Uptown School Complex Principal Dr. Ananda Davis-Wright.

STEM education also flourished during the summer session. Principal Thomas Biggins of Pennsylvania Avenue School noted that students embraced STEM “not as an assignment, but as a passion.”

Both schools also operated Extended School Year (ESY) programs, which served students with Individualized Education Programs (IEPs). These programs provided consistency and helped minimize summer learning loss. “It helped keep some of our exceptional students in their routines,” Biggins said.

Throughout the summer, Dr. Davis-Wright managed responsibilities across both sites, beginning her mornings at Uptown to supervise transportation and continuing her day from a temporary office inside Pennsylvania Avenue School’s media center.

The upgrades at Uptown were part of Atlantic City Public Schools’ broader efforts to modernize facilities during the summer break. “These improvements were appreciated by all,” said Davis-Wright. “The **teachers will love it. The students will love it. And it addressed parents’ concerns.”

As the final construction work wrapped up, the spirit of teamwork and adaptability showcased how Atlantic City Public Schools continues to prioritize safety, community, and educational excellence. “It was a massive job,” Davis-Wright said. “You don’t realize how big it is until you watch it taking place.”

item.title: A Great Day on the Road: Atlantic City Senior Services Took a Trip to Remember
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City Senior Services hit the road with the Great Day Bus, taking seniors to Washington Township for a fun-filled shopping extravaganza. The day was packed with smiles, socializing, and plenty of purchases.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Senior Services team took their community on another exciting outing as part of their ongoing mission to keep seniors active, engaged, and connected. This time, seniors boarded the Great Day Bus and traveled to Washington Township for a delightful shopping extravaganza.

The day was filled with discovery and fun as participants explored a wide variety of shops and stores, enjoying the freedom to browse, shop, and socialize. With so many stores to visit and so many things to buy, the seniors embraced the opportunity to pick up essentials, gifts, and a few well-deserved treats for themselves.

The outing wasn’t just about shopping—it was also about building memories and nurturing friendships. For many, it was a refreshing change of pace, and for some, a chance to visit a new place with the comfort of familiar faces and supportive staff from Atlantic City Senior Services.

The Great Day Bus lived up to its name, providing a safe and comfortable ride while also serving as a rolling reminder of the city's dedication to its senior community. Laughter, conversation, and shared stories filled the bus as the group returned home with shopping bags—and smiles—in hand.

This trip was part of a broader initiative by Atlantic City to offer enriching experiences that support seniors’ emotional, physical, and social well-being. These excursions continue to prove that staying active and connected is not only possible—it’s a priority.

item.title: Atlantic City Welcomed Pilots Ahead of Thrilling Shore & Soar Airshow
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Atlantic City welcomed pilots and performers ahead of the Air Show with a coordinated safety briefing involving local and state agencies. The city ensured a safe and thrilling event through proactive planning and collaboration.
item.content:encoded:
The City of Atlantic City proudly welcomed an elite group of pilots and performers ahead of the highly anticipated Atlantic City Shore & Soar Air Show. Prior to taking flight, these skilled professionals met with public safety officials and Air Show organizers to finalize all plans and protocols, ensuring a safe and thrilling experience for everyone attending.

Held on the iconic Atlantic City shoreline, this annual event drew participants from various aviation sectors. The collaboration between the Atlantic City Police Department, Office of Emergency Management, AtlantiCare, New Jersey State Police, and Atlantic City Beach Patrol showcased the city's commitment to safety and efficiency during large-scale events.

As planes soared above the city skyline and over the Atlantic Ocean, attendees enjoyed an awe-inspiring display of precision and power, backed by careful behind-the-scenes planning. The pilots’ pre-show briefing reflected Atlantic City’s proactive approach, with each agency playing a key role in ensuring a smooth and secure program for visitors and residents alike.

The city extended its appreciation and best wishes to all pilots and performers, recognizing their dedication, skill, and the excitement they brought to Atlantic City. The community turned out in full force to celebrate the skies, proving once again that Atlantic City is more than just a destination — it’s a city built for experiences that uplift and unite.

item.title: Rowing Year 3 Launched Stronger Than Ever in Atlantic City
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Rowing Year 3 officially kicked off with renewed energy and record participation, marking a strong start to Atlantic City’s growing youth sports program. This year’s launch was bigger, better, and full of momentum.
item.content:encoded:
The Atlantic City Recreation Department proudly launched Rowing Year 3, marking another milestone in the city’s growing commitment to youth sports, outdoor activities, and community development through recreation.

This third year of rowing kicked off with great momentum, drawing even more excitement and participation than in previous years. The event began with strong energy and anticipation from returning athletes, new participants, and families who gathered to support the program.

Organized by AC Rec, this initiative had grown significantly, offering expanded access and greater opportunities for local youth to train, race, and thrive on the water. The program aimed not only to develop rowing skills but to instill confidence, discipline, and a sense of teamwork among the city’s young athletes.

The 2025 season featured a more robust schedule, improved equipment, and a larger network of coaches and volunteers. These enhancements reflected the department’s commitment to investing in youth recreation and building a foundation for long-term athletic development.

What made this year stand out was the increased visibility and enthusiasm from the community. Spectators, family members, and fellow residents turned out to witness the early practices and lend their support to the athletes as they prepared for upcoming races.

In collaboration with schools, city partners, and volunteers, the program also included educational sessions on water safety, physical conditioning, and team leadership. These additions provided participants with a well-rounded experience that extended beyond the water.

From the first stroke of the oars, the athletes demonstrated determination, teamwork, and pride—showcasing how much the program had evolved since its launch three years ago.

The Rowing Program continued to position Atlantic City as a hub for youth development through sport, blending athleticism with civic pride and community connection.

As the season unfolded, the excitement remained strong, with more races and milestones ahead. Residents were encouraged to follow along and support the program throughout the year.

To stay updated on future events, visit www.acnj.gov or follow Atlantic City Recreation on social media.

item.title: Atlantic City Public Schools Launched Major Summer Projects, Including New Jersey Avenue School Demolition
item.dc:creator: Great Day Atlantic City Contributors
item.description: Summer brought a wave of transformation to Atlantic City Public Schools, with the long-awaited demolition of New Jersey Avenue School paving the way for a brand-new administration building. The initiative reflected the district’s continued commitment to modernization, community needs, and long-term infrastructure improvement.
item.content:encoded:
While students and teachers enjoyed a well-earned break after the school year ended in June, Atlantic City Public Schools launched into a season of progress and preparation. The summer of 2025 was marked by critical upgrades, facility improvements, and one of the district’s most historic transitions—the demolition of the New Jersey Avenue School.

Located in the heart of the city, the New Jersey Avenue School had been closed since 2012, when the Pennsylvania Avenue School opened its doors. Later that same year, the building sustained severe damage during Hurricane Sandy, leaving it structurally compromised and unusable. For over a decade, the structure remained a silent witness to the city’s evolution—until this summer.

The district began preparing the site for a fresh start. Built in 1925, the school was set to be cleared to make room for a state-of-the-art administration building that will serve the entire district.

"We have committed to building an administration building," said Board of Education President Shay Steele. “This board, in conjunction with the leadership of Dr. Small, has made this project a priority. We are excited to fulfill the wishes of the community and also provide the district with a building of its own. This has been part of our mission, and upon completion we will have a state-of-the-art facility.”

According to Dr. Small, who began her teaching career at the New Jersey Avenue School in 2003, the new structure would centralize district operations and provide improved access for families, staff, and the community. She emphasized that the project represented more than just new construction—it embodied the district’s values of equity, excellence, and long-term investment.

“This is part of our ongoing commitment to modernize facilities and strengthen our infrastructure,” Dr. Small stated. “We want to ensure that both our students and our staff have the resources and support they need to succeed.”

Beyond the demolition, multiple summer projects were underway across the district. From classroom upgrades to campus repairs and efficiency improvements, the quiet summer months provided the perfect opportunity to enhance the learning environment before students returned in September.

The momentum reflected the district’s proactive approach to maintaining safe, functional, and inspiring schools. By taking advantage of the summer downtime, the district ensured that learning spaces were not just ready—but better than ever.

As the weeks progressed, Atlantic City Public Schools continued to update the community on ongoing projects and initiatives. The demolition of the New Jersey Avenue School served as both a symbolic and practical milestone—a reminder that even when classrooms are empty, the work of building a brighter future for Atlantic City never stopped.
